title: QMIR 2026 Syllabus
text:
Dates:



Class
Date




Monday
February 09, 2026


Thursday
February 12, 2026



Description:

Official welcome and introduction
What counts as an empirical claim in Political Science / IR
Data analysis vs statistical inference vs causal inference
Course expectations: coding, math, independence
Overview of the course workload and tools

Learning Objectives:

Understand the epistemic goals of quantitative research
Distinguish descriptive, inferential, and causal claims
Understand course structure, requirements, and assessment

Assignment: If you have not done so yet, please install all required software programs and packages.
Literature:

title: QMIR 2026 Syllabus
section: Session 2: Reproducible Research and the Computational Workflow
text:
Session 2: Reproducible Research and the Computational Workflow
Dates Monday: February 16, 2026 Thursday: February 19, 2026
Description:

Scientific knowledge as a computational process
Reproducibility vs replicability
Research artifacts: scripts, notebooks, reports
Project structure, file paths, and version control
Deterministic vs stochastic workflows
Algorithms and pseudocode as formal reasoning tools

Learning Objectives:

Understand reproducibility as a scientific norm
Organize empirical research as a structured project
Use Quarto and Git to create reproducible analyses

Assignment:

Set up a reproducible Quarto project with Git
Produce deterministic and stochastic outputs
Brief written reflection on reproducibility vs replicability

Literature:

title: QMIR 2026 Syllabus
section: Session 3: Data, Objects, and Formal Representation in R
text:
Session 3: Data, Objects, and Formal Representation in R
Dates Monday: February 23, 2026 Thursday: February 26, 2026
Description:

Programming as formalization of assumptions
Objects, functions, and assignment
Core data structures in R
Variable types and missing values
Tidy data principles

Learning Objectives:

Write and read basic R code
Understand how data are represented computationally
Prepare data for analysis and modeling

Assignment:

Clean and restructure a messy dataset
Convert to tidy format
Explicitly document variable types and missingness

Literature:

title: QMIR 2026 Syllabus
section: Session 4: Data Transformation, Integration, and Visual Reasoning
text:
Session 4: Data Transformation, Integration, and Visual Reasoning
Dates Monday: March 02, 2026 Thursday: March 05, 2026
Description:

Subsetting and aggregation as analytical choices
Merging datasets and identifiers
Missing data as a substantive problem
Visualization as reasoning, not decoration
Visualizing uncertainty

Learning Objectives:

Combine multiple data sources correctly
Diagnose data problems using visualization
Produce interpretable and honest graphics

Assignment:
Literature:

title: QMIR 2026 Syllabus
section: Session 5: Exploratory Data Analysis as Model Critique
text:
Session 5: Exploratory Data Analysis as Model Critique
Dates: Monday: March 09, 2026 Thursday: March 12, 2026
Description:

EDA as structured learning from data
Descriptive vs inferential summaries
Distributional thinking and outliers
Transformations and sensitivity
EDA as preparation for modeling

Learning Objectives:

Conduct systematic exploratory data analysis
Identify patterns, anomalies, and modeling implications
Avoid overinterpretation at the descriptive stage

Assignment:

Full EDA report on a dataset
Include summaries, plots, and transformations
End with proposed modeling assumptions

Literature:

title: QMIR 2026 Syllabus
section: Session 7: Research Design, Causality, and Inferential Targets
text:
Session 7: Research Design, Causality, and Inferential Targets
Dates Monday: March 23, 2026 Thursday: March 26, 2026
Description:

From research to questions to inferential targets
Generative models and causal stories
DAGs as representations of assumptions
Parameters, estimands, and estimates
Identifiability, uncertainty, and assumptions

Learning Objectives:

Translate substantive questions into estimands
Understand the role of assumptions in inference
Distinguish uncertainty due to data vs design

Assignment:

Research design memo
Define a research question and estimand
Draw a DAG
Discuss identification challenges and assumptions

Literature:

title: QMIR 2026 Syllabus
section: Session 8: Linear Regression as a Generative Probabilistic Model
text:
Session 8: Linear Regression as a Generative Probabilistic Model
Dates Monday: April 13, 2026 Thursday: April 16, 2026
Description:

Regression as conditional expectation
Gaussian likelihood and noise
Bayesian workflow: priors, checks, estimation
Posterior interpretation and prediction
Model critique and misspecification

Learning Objectives:

Specify and estimate Bayesian linear models
Interpret regression results probabilistically
Diagnose model fit and assumptions

Assignment:

Fit a Bayesian linear regression
Conduct prior and posterior predictive checks
Report quantities of interest with uncertainty

Literature:

title: QMIR 2026 Syllabus
section: Session 9: Multivariate Models, Controls, and Effect Heterogeneity
text:
Session 9: Multivariate Models, Controls, and Effect Heterogeneity
Dates Monday: April 20, 2026 Thursday: April 23, 2026
Description:

Conditional relationships and omitted variable bias
Controls guided by DAGs
Dummy variables and continuous controls
Interactions as conditional effects
Multicollinearity as an information problem

Learning Objectives:

Specify multivariate regression models
Interpret interactions using predictions
Justify control strategies

Assignment:

Estimate a multivariate model with interactions
Visualize conditional effects
Explain results without relying on coefficients alone

Literature:

title: QMIR 2026 Syllabus
section: Session 10: Binary Outcome Models and Probabilistic Prediction
text:
Session 10: Binary Outcome Models and Probabilistic Prediction
Dates Monday: April 27, 2026 Thursday: April 30, 2026
Description:

Modeling discrete outcomes
Bernoulli likelohood and link functions
Logistic regression intuition
Prediction and counterfactuals
Separation and instability

Learning Objectives:

Model binary outcomes probabilistically
Interpret predicted probabilities and uncertainty
Conduct counterfactual predictions

Assignment:

Fit a Bayesian logistic regression
Generate predicted probabilities
Perform and interpret a counterfactual scenario

Literature:

title: QMIR 2026 Syllabus
section: Session 11: Hierarchical Data Structures I (Fixed Effects Models)
text: Session 11: Hierarchical Data Structures I (Fixed Effects Models)

title: QMIR 2026 Syllabus
section: Session 12: Hierarchical Data Structures II (Multilevel Models)
text: Session 12: Hierarchical Data Structures II (Multilevel Models)

title: QMIR 2026 Syllabus
text:
Session 13: Semester Wrap Up
Dates Monday: May 18, 2026 Thursday: May 28, 2026
Description:

Writing results with uncertainty language
Common inferential fallacies
Transparency and reporting standards
Reproducibility checklist
From coursework to Bachlor thesis (QuickQuartoSetup)

Learning Objectives:

Communicate results responsibly
Apply reproducibility standards
Prepare for independent research

Description:

Official welcome and introduction
What counts as an empirical claim in Political Science / IR
Data analysis vs statistical inference vs causal inference
Course expectations: coding, math, independence
Overview of the course workload and tools

Learning Objectives:

Understand the epistemic goals of quantitative research
Distinguish descriptive, inferential, and causal claims
Understand course structure, requirements, and assessment

Assignment: If you have not done so yet, please install all required software programs and packages.
Literature:

title: QMIR 2026 Syllabus
text:
Session 6: Probability as Epistemic Logic
Dates Monday: March 16, 2026 Thursday: March 19, 2026
Description:

Uncertainty as the starting point of inference
Probability as a logic of plausibility
Conditional reasoning and Bayesâ€™ rule
Prior, likelihood, and posterior

Learning Objectives:

Interpret probability as degree of uncertainty
Understand Bayesian updating conceptually
See data as realizations of a generative process

Assignment:

Specify a simple generative model
Simulate prior predictive data
Update beliefs with observed data
Visualize prior vs posterior distributions

Literature:

title: QMIR 2026 Syllabus
section: Session 11: Fixed Effects and Within-Unit Inference
text:
Session 11: Fixed Effects and Within-Unit Inference
Dates Monday: May 04, 2026 Thursday: May 07, 2026
Description:

Hierarchical data structures
Logic of fixed effects
Within-unit vs between-unit variation
Interpretation and information loss
Limits of fixed effects

Learning Objectives:

Understand what fixed effects identify
Interpret coefficients correctly
Recognize trade-offs of FE models

Assignment:

Compare pooled and fixed-effects models
Interpret differences substantively
Reflect on identification trade-offs

Literature:

title: QMIR 2026 Syllabus
section: Session 12: Multilevel Models and Partial Pooling
text:
Session 12: Multilevel Models and Partial Pooling
Dates Monday: May 11, 2026 Thursday: May 21, 2026
Description:

Pooling strategies
Random intercepts and slopes
Shrinkage and bias-variance tradeoff
Exchangebility assumptions
When multilevel models fail

Learning Objectives:

Specify and interpret multilevel models
Understand partial pooling substantively
Decide when hierarchical models are appropriate

Assignment:

Fit a multilevel model
Compare to pooled and FE alternatives
Interpret shrinkage effects

title: QMIR 2026
text:
Welcome to the course website of quantitative methods in international relations 2026!
You can find the course outline here.
